#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XXXV

#Text=Edmund had determined that it belonged entirely to Fanny to chuse whether her situation with regard to Crawford should be mentioned between them or not ; and that if she did not lead the way , it should never be touched on by him ; but after a day or two of mutual reserve , he was induced by his father to change his mind , and try what his influence might do for his friend .

#Text=A day , and a very early day , was actually fixed for the Crawfords ' departure ; and Sir Thomas thought it might be as well to make one more effort for the young man before he left Mansfield , that all his professions and vows of unshaken attachment might have as much hope to sustain them as possible .
#Text=Sir Thomas was most cordially anxious for the perfection of Mr. Crawford 's character in that point .
#Text=He wished him to be a model of constancy ; and fancied the best means of effecting it would be by not trying him too long .
#Text=Edmund was not unwilling to be persuaded to engage in the business ; he wanted to know Fanny 's feelings .

#Text=She had been used to consult him in every difficulty , and he loved her too well to bear to be denied her confidence now ; he hoped to be of service to her , he thought he must be of service to her ; whom else had she to open her heart to ?
#Text=If she did not need counsel , she must need the comfort of communication .

#Text=Fanny estranged from him , silent and reserved , was an unnatural state of things ; a state which he must break through , and which he could easily learn to think she was wanting him to break through .

#Text=“ I will speak to her , sir : I will take the first opportunity of speaking to her alone , ” was the result of such thoughts as these ; and upon Sir Thomas 's information of her being at that very time walking alone in the shrubbery , he instantly joined her .
#Text=“ I am come to walk with you , Fanny , ” said he .
#Text=“ Shall I ? ” Drawing her arm within his .
#Text=“ It is a long while since we have had a comfortable walk together . ”
#Text=She assented to it all rather by look than word .
#Text=Her spirits were low .
#Text=“ But , Fanny , ” he presently added , “ in order to have a comfortable walk , something more is necessary than merely pacing this gravel together .
#Text=You must talk to me .
#Text=I know you have something on your mind .
#Text=I know what you are thinking of .
#Text=You cannot suppose me uninformed .
#Text=Am I to hear of it from everybody but Fanny herself ? ”
#Text=Fanny , at once agitated and dejected , replied , “ If you hear of it from everybody , cousin , there can be nothing for me to tell . ”
#Text=“ Not of facts , perhaps ; but of feelings , Fanny .
#Text=No one but you can tell me them .
#Text=I do not mean to press you , however .
#Text=If it is not what you wish yourself , I have done .
#Text=I had thought it might be a relief . ”
#Text=“ I am afraid we think too differently for me to find any relief in talking of what I feel . ”
#Text=“ Do you suppose that we think differently ?
#Text=I have no idea of it .

#Text=I dare say that , on a comparison of our opinions , they would be found as much alike as they have been used to be : to the point -- I consider Crawford 's proposals as most advantageous and desirable , if you could return his affection .
#Text=I consider it as most natural that all your family should wish you could return it ; but that , as you cannot , you have done exactly as you ought in refusing him .
#Text=Can there be any disagreement between us here ? ”
#Text=“ Oh no !
#Text=But I thought you blamed me .
#Text=I thought you were against me .
#Text=This is such a comfort ! ”
#Text=“ This comfort you might have had sooner , Fanny , had you sought it .
#Text=But how could you possibly suppose me against you ?
#Text=How could you imagine me an advocate for marriage without love ?
#Text=Were I even careless in general on such matters , how could you imagine me so where your happiness was at stake ? ”
#Text=“ My uncle thought me wrong , and I knew he had been talking to you . ”
#Text=“ As far as you have gone , Fanny , I think you perfectly right .
#Text=I may be sorry , I may be surprised -- though hardly that , for you had not had time to attach yourself -- but I think you perfectly right .
#Text=Can it admit of a question ?
#Text=It is disgraceful to us if it does .
#Text=You did not love him ; nothing could have justified your accepting him . ”
#Text=Fanny had not felt so comfortable for days and days .
#Text=“ So far your conduct has been faultless , and they were quite mistaken who wished you to do otherwise .
#Text=But the matter does not end here .
#Text=Crawford 's is no common attachment ; he perseveres , with the hope of creating that regard which had not been created before .
#Text=This , we know , must be a work of time .
#Text=But ” ( with an affectionate smile )
#Text=“ let him succeed at last , Fanny , let him succeed at last .
#Text=You have proved yourself upright and disinterested , prove yourself grateful and tender-hearted ; and then you will be the perfect model of a woman which I have always believed you born for . ”
#Text=“ Oh !
#Text=never , never , never !
#Text=he never will succeed with me . ”
#Text=And she spoke with a warmth which quite astonished Edmund , and which she blushed at the recollection of herself , when she saw his look , and heard him reply , “ Never !
#Text=Fanny ! -- so very determined and positive !
#Text=This is not like yourself , your rational self . ”
